inscription:
Signature, Title, Date, Inscription and Edition

LRQ panel a: In 807 A.D., The King of Persia / presents Charlemagne / a waterclock made of / bronze inlaid with gold // The dial has twelve little / doors. On the hour, a door / opens and out drop little / balls on a brass drum. // Charlemagne hears what / time it is by counting strikes / on the drum. He sees the / time by counting open doors. // At twelve o'clock, twelve / horsemen in miniature come / out to shut the doors. The / clock then drains and resets. 

LRC panel b: Cone inverted in funnel / regulates flow of water into / calibrated cylinder. Surplus / water escapes via overflow.

URC panel c: Metered water slowly rises / in cylinder. Float in cylinder / raises Rack. Pointer on rack / indicates hours on vertical dial | LRC: Charlemagne cannot read nor / write. He signs his name with / a lozenge within a lozenge. / A scribe adds four initials.
medium: Screenprint and gold leaf over gesso and acrylic paint, triptych
provenance: The artist, Minneapolis; given to MIA, 2015.
signed: bottom, in pencil: 8/15 The Three Snares (Waterclock) Philip Larson 1984
text: Trained in philosophy, archeology, and art history, Philip Larson uses the visual vocabulary of architecture and design to inform his sculpture and graphic art. His work usually features iconic architectural elements reconfigured into novel permutations of geometric form. These design elements range from ancient Egyptian and Native American glyphs, to Prairie School, Art Deco, and Postmodern ornamentation. Through a process of appropriation and transformation, Larson invests these decorative motifs with symbolic and emotive value. In reconfiguring these motifs, he stresses their aesthetic and conceptual characteristics as formal visual systems.
title: Charlemagne Water Clock (Waterclock I-III)
